Terminate a process prematurely before it finishes.
Entity (person or system) that participates in or initiates a process.
Adjust to new conditions or requirements in a project or system.
User with privileges to manage and configure a system or application.
Take up or start using something new, such as a technology or practice.
Background service or process that performs automated tasks on a schedule.
Software development approach emphasizing flexibility and iterative progress.
Notification of an urgent issue, prompting immediate attention.
System-generated warning or notification about a specific condition.
Alternate name or shorthand for an object or person in a system.
Ensure components or stakeholders are in agreement on goals and approach.
Early test version of software with incomplete features.
Ordered collection of elements accessed by an index in programming.
Item of value owned by a person or company, tracked in systems.
Not occurring at the same time, allowing processes to run independently.
Sound content or signals processed or produced by an application.
Systematic record or log of actions for accountability and review.
Microsoft’s cloud computing platform for deploying applications and services.
Execution of jobs or tasks in large groups without manual intervention.
Distinct identity of a product or company, shaped by its name and reputation.
Pause execution or exit from a loop or process, often used in debugging.
Compile and assemble code into a working application or component.
Person or organization that purchases goods or services.
Units of data, typically groups of 8 bits, used to measure storage or memory.
Temporary storage that saves recently used data for quicker access.
Instances of work or transactions managed in a workflow application.
Intercept and handle an error thrown during program execution.
Series of connected elements or processes, like steps in a supply sequence.
Leading contender in a test, often paired with a “challenger” in experiments.
Visual diagram representing data or information (e.g., bar or pie).
Verify correctness or presence of something, often as part of testing.
Dependent element that derives from a parent entity, such as a sub-case.
Request for benefit or payment, especially in insurance or healthcare.
Blueprint or template defining the structure and behavior of objects.
Free of errors or extraneous elements, such as well-prepared data.
Remove all contents or reset to an empty or default state.
Mark a case or process as completed or no longer active.
Infrastructure of remote servers accessed via the internet for data storage and computing.
Mentor or guide who supports a team in improving performance (commonly in Agile).
One who writes computer programs; a software developer.
Hue or shade used in design elements, often to improve user experience.
Expenses or resources required for a project or purchase.
Abrupt failure of a program or system, causing it to stop working.
Relating to computers or networks, often used when discussing digital security.
Complete series of stages or events that repeat in sequence.
Process of identifying and resolving bugs or issues in software.
Single numerical character (0–9) used in representing numbers.
Marked as modified or unsaved, indicating changes that need saving.
Preliminary version of a document or design, subject to change.
Explore data at deeper levels of detail, as in diving into specifics.
Placeholder or sample used during development in place of real data.
Electronic message sent over a network, a common communication method in business.
Item of data entered into a system, or a record in a list or log.
Having the same value or status, often used in comparisons.
Flaw in software causing incorrect results or failure in execution.
Moral principle guiding responsible behavior in technology or business.
Occurrence or action that triggers processes or responses in a system.
Widely used spreadsheet software, often integrated for data export/import.
Verified pieces of information used as evidence or reference.
Boolean value indicating a negative or “no” condition.
Causing a program or process to terminate immediately due to a critical error.
Retrieve data from a source, such as calling an API or database query.
Individual data element or input area within a form or record.
Corrections applied to bugs or issues in software.
Group of vehicles or resources managed together, common in logistics.
Numeric data type for decimals, or to position an element to one side in layout.
Process diagrams or paths outlining how work moves through a system.
Sets of typefaces used in text display for consistent style.
User interface screens or documents with fields for inputting data.
Online platform where users discuss topics or ask and answer questions.
Structural element or outline that contains or supports content.
Intentional deception for personal or financial gain, often fought with detection systems.
Specific objectives or targets that an individual or organization aims to achieve.
Rank or category assigned based on quality, performance, or other criteria.
Officially give or allow something, such as permission or funding.
Diagram of connected points or nodes showing relationships or data changes.
Refine and prioritize items (like backlog tasks) in preparation for development.
Collection of users or items considered as a single unit for organization or access.
Protective measure to prevent errors or enforce standards (often used with “rails”).
Establishment offering lodging to travelers, often booked through reservation systems.
Picture or graphic file used in an interface or processed by a system.
Personal worklist or mail folder where pending items or messages arrive.
Database structure that improves lookup speed by organizing data on key fields.
Data provided to a system or program for processing.
Problem or bug that needs to be resolved in a system or project.
Text caption identifying a field or element in a user interface.
Parallel tracks in a process diagram separating responsibilities or roles.
Level of abstraction in a system architecture or stack.
Potential customers or clients that have shown interest, to be pursued by sales.
Acquire knowledge or skills through study, practice, or experience.
Position in a hierarchy or scale, often indicating degree or difficulty.
Money lent that is expected to be paid back, usually with interest.
Relating to a specific machine or environment (as opposed to remote or global).
Set of reasoning steps or rules that determines how decisions are made.
Process of entering credentials to gain access to a system.
Faithful and committed, as in long-term customers or employees.
Single command or abbreviation that expands into a set of instructions or operations.
Combine multiple elements (such as code branches or data sets) into one.
Very small in scale; often describes extremely granular components in a system architecture.
Simulated objects or components used in testing to mimic real ones.
Pop-up dialog that requires user interaction before returning to main workflow.
Abstract representation or blueprint, often for a system or predictive algorithm.
Currency or funds used as a medium of exchange in transactions.
Object or mechanism that prevents simultaneous access to a resource (mutual exclusion).
Annotations or comments added to provide context or record information.
Proposal of a product, service, or incentive presented to a customer.
Request for a product or service, placed by a customer for fulfillment.
Individual accountable for a task, case, or system resource.
Sections or screens in an application, or data containers in memory.
Dedicated section of a user interface or a group discussion on a specific topic.
Variable used to pass information into a process or function.
Analyze text or data by breaking it into components that can be used.
Software update designed to fix bugs or security vulnerabilities.
Entity responsible for payment, such as an insurer covering a claim.
Distinct stage of a project or process with specific objectives.
Voice communication device or channel, often integrated into customer service systems.
Small-scale trial of a new system or process before full deployment.
Single unit of measurement or detail (e.g., an Agile estimation metric).
Shared resource group or partition within a workflow or process diagram.
Assigned cost or monetary value of a product or service.
Output text or data, typically for display or logging.
Server or component that acts on behalf of another to forward requests or data.
Internal feed or stream for collaboration updates within a system.
Structured request to retrieve or manipulate data from a database.
List of items waiting to be processed, typically in order of arrival or priority.
Formal statement of price or terms for products or services.
Guiding tracks that keep development or processes within set boundaries.
Span between minimum and maximum values, or extent of variation.
Pattern defined by a regular expression, used for matching strings in text.
Respond to a message or communication.
Restore settings or data to their initial default state.
Agile meeting held after a sprint to reflect and plan improvements.
Attempt an operation again after a failure or error.
Utilize existing components or resources instead of creating new ones.
Potential issues or uncertainties that could negatively impact a project.
Automated bot or machine that performs tasks without human intervention.
Defined positions or functions that determine access rights and responsibilities.
Send or direct something along a specific path or to a particular destination.
Business logic definitions in a system that determine behavior or outcomes.
Activities related to selling products or services and managing customer relationships.
Increase size or capacity to handle growing demand or volume.
Defined boundaries of a project or process, specifying what’s included and excluded.
Numerical rating indicating performance, priority, or likelihood (e.g., credit rating).
Agile framework with time-boxed iterations and regular team ceremonies.
Initial configuration or arrangement needed to prepare a system for use.
Graphic element (like an icon) representing a step or control in a process flow.
Give others access to or use of something, such as information or resources.
Sixth letter of the Greek alphabet, commonly used as a symbol in quality management methods.
Isolated groups or systems that do not effectively communicate or share information.
Expertise or ability that can be applied to perform tasks or roles.
Automated or intelligent, often describing systems that make decisions on their own.
Preliminary test run to catch basic issues before formal testing.
Short research or prototyping effort to investigate a solution approach.
Divide or break something into separate parts or branches.
Small, cross-functional team working together on a project.
Collection of technologies or layers that form a complete platform or solution.
Employees or personnel collectively within an organization.
Major phase in a case lifecycle or project, containing related steps.
Personal or financial interest or share in an endeavor, held by someone involved.
Out-of-date or no longer fresh; data that has not been refreshed recently.
Current condition or status of an object or process at a point in time.
Numerical metrics or data summaries that measure performance or outcomes.
Individual actions or tasks that are part of a larger process sequence.
Supply of goods available, or equity shares in a company.
Save data or keep something in a repository for later use.
Brief description of a requirement told from an end-user perspective (Agile context).
Minimal placeholder functions or components used to simulate parts of a system during testing.
Consistent design or formatting conventions applied for a uniform look and feel.
Collection of related tools or applications offered as a package.
Prefix indicating elevated privileges or an extreme degree (as in a user with all access).
Structured arrangement of data in rows and columns, such as in a spreadsheet.
Mandatory fees charged by a government on income, sales, etc., calculated by finance systems.
Groups of people collaborating together towards a common goal.
Procedures executed to verify that a system works as intended.
Overall design style or look-and-feel applied across an application.
Explicitly generate an error or exception in a program to signal an issue.
Mechanism that triggers an action after a specified time interval.
Brief message that pops up in the UI to notify the user and then fades away.
Utilities or software applications used to accomplish development or administrative tasks.
Detailed log or recording of step-by-step execution flow for debugging.
Exchange of goods, services, or assets between parties.
Teach or instruct people (or in AI, provide data to a model to learn from).
Hierarchical structures with branches, used to represent data or decisions.
General direction of change or development over time.
Test run or evaluation period for a product or solution before full rollout.
Confidence in the reliability or integrity of a system, product, or team.
Individuals who interact with a system or application to perform tasks.
Importance, worth, or benefit of something, often measured against cost.
Secure repository for sensitive information, protected by encryption or access controls.
Medium for transmitting moving visual images and sound, used in calls or media playback.
Strategic plan or long-term goal that guides a project or organization.
Audio-based communication or control interface, such as speech input or output.
Unnecessary work or resources that do not add value, targeted for elimination.
Loop that continues executing as long as its condition remains true.
Creative concepts or suggestions intended to solve problems or improve outcomes.
Maximum boundary or allowed value that should not be exceeded.
Fast-paced or quick, often describing accelerated development or change.
Single page of a workbook or document used for organizing information.
Command-line interface used to enter and execute text-based commands.
Pieces of work to be completed, often tracked on a to-do list or project plan.
